title: California Issues First Fracking Permits In Nine Months. But COVID-19 Makes It Even More Complicated.
summary:
For the first time since last summer, California oil and gas regulators have approved permits for a controversial drilling practice called hydraulic fracturing, or fracking.
Last Friday the California Geologic Energy Management Division, CalGEM, issued two dozen new permits for fracking wells.
Environmentalists have long opposed the methods and say with COVID-19 the timing couldn’t be worse.
Advocates say they expect more and the state still has 282 fracking permits that could be permitted, the Associated Press reports.
The thought of new oil wells operating in Kern County worries some residents, especially as the number of COVID-19 cases rises.

title: Coronavirus: California issues stay home order, global death toll surpasses 10,000
summary:
— Meredith4:16 pm: Global death toll surpasses 10,000The global death toll from the coronavirus pandemic has risen above 10,000, according to data from Johns Hopkins University.
The exact number stood at 10,031 on Friday morning with total confirmed cases at 244,523.
India has at least 173 confirmed cases, out of which 19 have been cured and four people have died.
The country has reported a total of 80,967 confirmed cases and 3,248 deaths, while 71,150 people have been discharged.
The state reported nearly 699 confirmed cases as of 9 p.m.

title: Two earthquakes strike Northern and Southern California
summary:
LOS ANGELES (AP) — In these dark times, clouded by fears of an enemy we can’t see and sheltered in homes we're itching to leave, it's reassuring to know that California's sunsets over the Pacific are just as vivid.
You just can't enjoy them with sand between your toes.
Most beaches and virtually every other destination in California are closed because of the coronavirus outbreak.
Gavin Newsom has written off the possibility of a typical summer.
It could be one where you travel on the internet, have your temperature checked before being seated in a half-empty restaurant and worry about tan lines from your face mask.

title: Bruins mourn loss of former teammate Colby Cave
summary:
Oilers forward Colby Cave, who underwent emergency surgery on his brain on Tuesday, died Saturday morning.
A member of the Bruins’ organization as recently as January, 2019, Cave spent four-plus seasons with the AHL’s Providence Bruins.
Edmonton Oilers forward Colby Cave, who spent most of his five-year pro career in the Bruins organization, died on Saturday morning.
"The Bruins were attempting to return Cave to Providence when the Oilers claimed him on waivers on Jan. 15, 2019.
Cave played 11 NHL games this season, the last one on Feb. 21 against the Wild.

title: Kern County’s unemployment rate rises to 8.6% in January
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — January’s unemployment numbers in Kern County saw a jump from the previous reporting period according to state officials.
The Employment Development Department says the unemployment rate for Kern County in January was 8.6%.
The rate is up from 7.1% in December, but remains lower than January 2019 which was at 9%.
For comparison, California’s unemployment rate was at 4.3% in January continuing historic low rates.

title: Pregnant mother dies after being given pain medication at California hospital, family left with questions
summary:
The family told KERO that Sabrina De La Rosa was a healthy mother of three who was about to give birth again.
She was given pain medication and was told she would be discharged.
According to De La Rosa’s family, the nurse informed them that her OB-GYN, Dr. Jason Helliwell, approved pain medication that was administered to De La Rosa.
According to De La Rosa’s family, she was first given a shot of pain medication.
Borgna said that’s how the family found out the dosage and the name of the pain medication that was administered.

title: Three hurt after rollover crash in southwest Bakersfield
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) – Three people were hurt after a rollover crash happened in southwest Bakersfield Sunday night.
According to the Bakersfield Police Department, officers responded to the intersection of Ming Avenue and Valhalla Drive around 7:15 p.m. to reports of a crash.
When officers arrived, they say two cars had major damage after a rollover crash occurred.
According to officers, two adults and a child suffered minor to moderate injuries and were taken to the hospital.
The crash is still under investigation.

summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — A family is devastated and traumatized after they say their loved one died after being admitted into Memorial Hospital in Bakersfield.
The family told 23ABC today that Sabrina De La Rosa was a healthy mother of three, who was about to give birth again.
Moments later the family was notified that De La Rosa was admitted to the hospital.

title: Thousands descend on Downtown Bakersfield for third annual Women’s March Kern County
summary:
The third annual Women’s March Kern County took place in Downtown Bakersfield Saturday.
The event started at 10 am at Central Park at Mill Creek on 21st Street and ended after the march at 3 pm.
“It’s all about empowering women and the community,” said co-director Robin Walters.
The father of two attending today’s festivities to give thanks to all the women in his life.
To learn more about Women’s March Kern County click here.

title: Bakersfield City Council votes to table homeless shelter vote until January 2020
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — The Bakersfield City Council voted unanimously to delay going forward with a letter of intent to purchase the property located at 1900 East Brundage Avenue that would be transformed into a new 450-bed homeless shelter.
Council members heard out community members as they expressed concerns surrounding neighborhood safety and the size of the facility.
The motion was passed to table the vote until January 22, 2020 and council asked city staff to perform a comprehensive budget analysis and reach out to the community for feedback.

title: Man survives train collision in East Bakersfield
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — A man is recovering at a hospital after he struck by a train Thursday night in East Bakersfield.
Crews were called to the the tracks at Laguna Seca Way and Oswell Street just before 8 p.m.A sheriff’s office spokesperson said the man suffered injuries to his legs and will be taken to a hospital for treatment.
He is expected to survive his injuries.
It’s unclear how or why the man was on or near the tracks.
BNSF police are conducting the investigation.

title: Earthquake: 3.3 quake strikes in Oildale, Calif.
summary:
A magnitude 3.3 earthquake was reported Wednesday at 4:56 a.m. Pacific time in Oildale, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
The earthquake occurred two miles from Bakersfield, four miles from Shafter, seven miles from Rosedale and 11 miles from Lamont.
In the last 10 days, there has been one earthquake of magnitude 3.0 or greater centered nearby.
AdvertisementThe earthquake occurred at a depth of 10.2 miles.
Even if you didn’t feel this small earthquake, you never know when the Big One is going to strike.

title: Is Bakersfield prepared for the big one?
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — We all know that being fully prepared for a major earthquake isn't a simple task.
But when it comes to the question of if Bakersfield is prepared for the big one, the city has a simple answer.
We're confident that we can handle that," said Joe Conroy, a spokesman for the City of Bakersfield.
In 1952 the Tehachapi earthquake killed 12 people in the county and destroyed many buildings in Bakersfield.
Even though officials are confident we're ready for another big one, the City of Bakersfield and Kern County are currently working together to update their emergency response plan and learn where we are most vulnerable.

title: Magnitude 3.2 earthquake shakes NNE of Oildale
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) – A 3.2 magnitude earthquake shook north northeast of Oildale Wednesday morning just before 5 a.m. according to the U.S. Geological SurveyUSGS located the epicenter near Seven Sisters Road in Oildale, just north of Manor Street and west of North Chester Avenue.
Shaking was reported to be felt in the Bakersfield area.
The quake was initially reported as a 3.3-magnitude earthquake but was later downgraded to a 3.2 by USGS.
You can see the latest information on this quake at this link.

title: Public Health discusses coronavirus risk to Kern County
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) – Kern Public Health briefed the board of supervisors on coronavirus at their meeting Tuesday.
Health officials say the virus has symptoms very similar to the seasonal flu such as a cough, fever, chills and a respiratory like illness.
Despite the proximity to Kern County, Public Health says it’s unlikely we’ll see a case here at home.
Kern County Public Health says they are working with health officials to monitor the virus.
Corson says there are no special precautions the public needs to take at this time.

Officials said officers located a man, later identified as Angel Hermosillo-Rivera, who matched the description and was eventually arrested after investigation.
Hermosillo-Rivera was arrested and booked into the Kern County Jail on various sexual assault charges.
Hermosillo-Rivera is due in court on Jan. 28, according to a Kern County inmate database.

title: Firefighters battle house inferno in South Bakersfield
summary:
Photo: KGET Digital Reporter, Karen Cruz-OrduñaBAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — Bakersfield Fire Department battled flames in a house located in South Bakersfield on Sunday around 8:40 a.m.
According to Bakersfield Fire Battalion Chief, Brad Ward, firefighters responded to a call about a house on fire at the 2600 block of South M Street.
Upon arrival, first responders found the structure completely engulfed in flames.
It took about 20 minutes for firefighters to get the fire under control.
According to the department, the house has been known to have homeless people live in it, from time to time.

summary:
— It is just under a week away from the 2020 Women’s March of Kern County.

Bakersfield fire says Austin Hanner, 18, was detained and had no visible injuries.
Both Jay Hanner, 59, and Matthew Hanner, 38, were taken to a local hospital to treat their burns.

City and county firefighters were called to a home in the 11000 block of Privet Place for a reported explosion.

title: Annual point-in-time count sees nearly 400 volunteers
summary:
— The annual point-in-time homeless count has gone electronic this year.
In the past, volunteers used hard copies to survey the homeless community in Kern County.
For the first time, the county has helped the Homeless Collaborative created an application that volunteers can use on their phone or tablet to conduct the survey.
Between 2018 and 2019, there was a 50% increase in the point-in-time homeless count throughout Kern County.
Last year, 931 male and 399 female homeless individuals were accounted for.

title: Dense fog causes school delays
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — A three-hour fog delay has been issued for the Rio Bravo-Greeley Union School District Tuesday morning.
Liberty High School has been issued a two-hour delay for certain bus routes.
Shafter High School and Richland School District have also been issued a two-hour fog delay.
Belridge Elementary School District has been issued a three-hour fog delay.
We will provide updates if other school delays are issued.

title: Judge issues ruling on cannabis Measure D ballot language
summary:
Measure D, one of two medicinal cannabis measures that qualified for the March ballot, seeks to legalize the sale of medicinal cannabis across the County.
Measure D is backed by the Central Valley Cannabis Association, also known as CVCA.
However, CVCA’s Measure D seeks to allow dispensaries that were open before 2018.
Judge Eric Bradshaw agreed, ordering CVCA to take out any reference to a supervisor in their ballot pro argument.
The County of Kern was nitpicking our ballot argument in favor of Measure D, at taxpayer expense.

title: Two people hospitalized in motorcycle, vehicle collision, CHP says
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — CHP says a motorcyclist and another vehicle collided on Rosedale Highway, east of Renfro Road, seriously injuring one person.
According to CHP, the crash happened around 9:30 p.m. Thursday night.
Police say the driver of a Honda, identified as 72-year-old Jeffrey Harmer, was turning into Rosedale Village Trailer Park when he turned in front of a motorcyclist.
The motorcyclist, identified as 19-year-old Caylob Pelayo, was traveling at an unknown speed and was ejected from his bike.
Pelayo was wearing a full-face helmet but suffered major injuries and taken to Kern Medical Center.

title: KHSD hosting Virtual Enterprises Conference at Mechanics Bank Theater and Convention Center
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — Students from all over California are participating in a two-day virtual conference and exhibition in Downtown Bakersfield.
There are 1500 students competing in the Virtual Enterprises California State Conference and Exhibition at Mechanics Bank Theater and Convention Center Wednesday and Thursday.
The top five teams will then advance to the Virtual Enterprise International Business Plan Competition in New York City in April.
Both Bakersfield High and Centennial High School Virtual Enterprise Firms have previously won first place in the national business plan competition.
The California Virtual Enterprise Trade Show features competitions in Marketing, Human Resources, Impact Marketing, Perfect Elevator Pitch, Salesmanship, and Web Design.

title: Final rounds of county high school mock trial competition wrap up
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) – UPDATE: Centennial High School came up victorious to win the 2020 Kern County Mock Trial Super Saturday.
The final two rounds of the Kern County Mock Trial Competition took place Saturday at the Kern County Superior Court in downtown Bakersfield followed by an awards ceremony.
Jacob Evans is an attorney for the Kern County Defenders Office and is an attorney coach for Ridgeview High School.
Centennial High School was awarded the 2020 Kern County Mock Trial Champions.
As Garces Memorial High School came in a close second, Liberty in third, Highland in fourth and Golden Valley in fifth place.

summary:

According to the BPD, a white SUV traveling northbound on Coffee Road on Tuesday night "made an unsafe lane change" and collided with a motorcycle.
The motorcyclist was transported to the hospital where he is listed in critical condition.
The driver, 40-year-old Trumonikia Fields-Johnson was arrested for hit-and-run and driving on a suspended license.
If you have any information regarding this accident, you are encouraged to call the Bakersfield Police Department at 661-327-7111.

title: Man shot in McFarland Saturday night
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET)– The McFarland Police Department are investigating a shooting that sent one man to the hospital Saturday night.
Officers responded to the shooting on the intersection of East Kern Avenue and Browning Road in McFarland around 7:30 p.m.
Upon their arrival, they found an adult male victim with a gunshot wound.
The man was transported to a nearby hospital and remains in stable condition.
There are no suspects at this time.

title: Arizona, California cases push US tally of new virus to 5
summary:
A patient in Southern California is third person in the U.S. to be diagnosed with the new pneumonia-like virus from China, health officials said.
Two new cases were reported Sunday — one in Los Angeles County in California and the other in Maricopa County, Arizona.
The latter case was someone with ties to Arizona State University who did not live in school housing and had a history of travel to Wuhan, China, state health officials said.
The patient was taken by ambulance to a hospital, health officials said at a Sunday news conference.
The three previously reported cases were a patient in Orange County, California; a man in his 30s in Washington state; and a woman in her 60s from Chicago.

title: ROC seeking community volunteers for upcoming conference
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — The Regional Occupational Center (ROC) is looking for community volunteers to help them host the SkillsUSA California Region 2 Conference on Feb. 22.
In order to put the event together, the local ROC office is asking the community for nearly 200 volunteers.
Volunteers can serve as either:Skill Competition JudgesLeadership Competition JudgesNon-Competing SkillsUSA / Courtesy CorpsGeneral VolunteerFor details on how to volunteer, click here.
The conference will be held at the ROC campus located at 501 S. Mt.
SkillsUSA is a national nonprofit organization that prepares middle school, high school, and college students for careers in trade, technical, and skilled service occupations.

title: Report: Renting is more affordable than buying a home in Kern County
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — According to an ATTOM Data Solutions report buying a home is more affordable than renting in 53% of the U.S. housing markets.
The report states that the average rent for 2020 in Kern County for a three-bedroom apartment is $1,461.
In comparison, last year the report states that the average rent was $1,429.
According to the report, the home prices from January to November in 2019 for Kern County were an average of $233,000.
However, in Los Angeles County the average was $645,000 and $1,550,000 in San Francisco County.

title: Kern Medical Center’s first baby of 2020 born at exactly midnight
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — Kern Medical Center had its first baby of the decade born exactly at midnight on Wednesday.
The baby girl, Alina Kaur Takhar, was born at seven pounds and four ounces.
According to the hospital, this is the first baby to be born at exactly midnight in the past several years.
Alina was one of roughly 390,000 babies born world wide on new year’s day, and one of 10,452 babies born across the country, according to UNICEF.
'”Additionally, three girls were born at Adventist Health Bakersfield, including a happy and healthy Estrella Corella, born at 12:10 a.m.All babies and their moms are doing well, per hospital staff.

title: House supply, sales dropped in Kern County last month
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — January saw home supply and demand in Kern County continue to decline, local appraiser Gary Crabtree says.
New listings last month dropped 6.4 percent from 722 in December 2019 to 676 last month.
Crabtree said home sales dropped 15.4 percent from 564 in December to 477.
However, Crabtree said what is unusual is that the median sale price dropped by $13,500 last month, or 5.1 percent.
The median price was $251,000 compared to $264,500 in December.

title: Bakersfield man wanted in Ventura for shooting his relative
summary:
Suspect: Vince Romero, 24Courtesy: Ventura Police DepartmentVENTURA, Calif. (KGET) — The manhunt is on for a Bakersfield man who was allegeldy involved in a shooting in Ventura County, Saturday morning.
Officers responded to a shooting in the 500 block of Thoreau Lane at 3:12 a.m. in Ventura.
Upon arrival, officers found a victim suffering from a gunshot wound to the leg.
Investigation revealed the victim and the suspect, 24 -year-old Vince Romero, are related and were involved in an altercation.
Anyone with information on this case is asked to call the Ventura Police Department at 805-339-4400.

title: State Bar suspends license of Bakersfield attorney for misconduct with multiple clients
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — The State Bar has placed Bakersfield attorney Gregory Mitts on suspension after he admitted to multiple counts of failing to respond to clients and failing to perform legal services with competence, according to State Bar court documents.
Mitts suspension was effective as of Dec. 1 and he is currently unable to practice law in California.
During his time representing those cases, the court said that Mitt's failed to inform client of significant developments, obey a court order and refund unearned fees.
Mitts failed to filed the petition in a timely manner, then failed to respond to the client's 11 written inquiries.
Mitts also failed to obey a court order to explain why the untimely filed petition should not be dismissed.

title: BPD investigating shooting outside Clinica Sierra Vista
summary:
UPDATE: The Bakersfield Police Department confirmed two men who were at Clinica Sierra Vista went outside and got into an argument where one shot at the other.
Both men left the scene and BPD has been unable to contact them at this time.
BPD confirms the incident was not an active shooter situation and the clinic was not targeted.
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET ) — The Bakersfield Police Department has confirmed that it has received reports of shots fired at the Clinica Sierra Vista building located at 2000 Physicians Boulevard.
The department said officers were sent to the area at around 11:30 a.m. No victims or suspects were immediately located.

title: Cumbia group Los Angeles Azules coming to Bakersfield this fall
summary:
The cumbia group Los Angeles Azules is coming to Bakersfield this fall.
The group will perform on Sept. 11 at the Mechanics Bank Arena, Theater and Convention Center, 1001 Truxtun Ave. Los Angeles Azules, the creators of the Symphonic Cumbia, will be coming to town as part of its Todos Somos Cumbia U.S. Tour 2020.

McFARLAND, Calif. (KGET) — The city of McFarland finds itself in deep financial trouble, and it’s taking a toll on public safety.
More than half of its police force has left McFarland for higher-paying jobs elsewhere, leaving the city with just five officers to answer emergency calls and patrol the city.
City leaders have tried to find ways to generate more revenue for city coffers, but have had limited success.
McFarland continues to struggle financially, but hasn’t yet been able to attract enough commercial development to strengthen city coffers.
Interim City Manager Larry Pennell will present his plan on what steps to take to save the city money, and how to generate more revenue.

title: U.S. foreclosure activity hits all-time low in February

Highest foreclosure rates in New Jersey, Illinois and DelawareNationwide one in every 2,841 housing units had a foreclosure filing in February 2020.
States with the highest foreclosure rates were New Jersey (one in every 1,457 housing units with a foreclosure filing); Illinois (one in every 1,507 housing units); Delaware (one in every 1,628 housing units); South Carolina (one in every 1,688 housing units); and Maryland (one in every 1,713 housing units).

title: 02.02.2020 is the first palindrome of its kind in over 900 years
summary:
TAMPA (WFLA) — We don’t need Punxsutawney Phil to tell us Sunday is forecast to be an incredibly unique day.
Feb. 2, 2020 (02-02-2020) is the first eight digit palindrome of its kind since 11-11-1111, University of Portland professor Aziz Inan told USA TODAY Saturday.
What makes the 02-02-2020 palindrome even more unique is that it also works internationally.
Whether you write the date in American order, day/month/year, or as many other countries do, month/day/year, it’s the same combination.
There won’t be another palindrome like this one for another 101 years – 12-12-2121.

title: CSUB inducts 4 to Alumni Hall of Fame
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — Four prominent community members were inducted into the CSUB Alumni Hall of Fame Friday night.
It’s the 14th year of the event that was held at Seven Oaks Country Club.
The Hall of Fame recognizes alumni who have made significant contributions in the community.
This year’s inductees include Blanca Cavazos, Alan Collatz, Judge Louie Vega and Colleen McGauley.
“It’s such a huge honor and to be with the three other honorees whose lives are inspirational, it’s another honor,” McGauley said.

title: BPD holding DUI/Driver’s License checkpoint Saturday night
summary:
The Bakersfield Police Department is conducting a DUI/Driver’s License checkpoint on Saturday.
The department said the checkpoint will take place at an undisclosed location within the city limits between the hours of 6 p.m. and 2 a.m. Officers will be looking for signs of alcohol and/or drug impairment, with officers checking drivers for proper licensing while delaying motorists momentarily.
Anyone who sees a possibly impaired driver is encouraged to call 911.

title: Thousands lose power in Central and South Bakersfield
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET)– Thousands of locals were without power after a massive PG&E power outage in Central and South Bakersfield, Sunday morning.
According to spokesperson for PG&E, JD Guidi , the power outage started at 7:09 a.m., causing 5,250 customers to lose power.
At 7:20 a.m., 3,300 customers had their power restored and by 8:33 a.m., all customers’ power had been restored.
Guidi said the cause of the outage is still being investigated by the utility company.

title: Crash flips car on its roof in downtown Bakersfield
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) – The Bakersfield Police Department is investigating what led to a rollover crash in downtown Bakersfield Monday night.
The accident took place just after 10:30 p.m. near the corner of 24th and H Streets.
The crash caused the car to be flipped over on its roof halfway up a curb.
Police are reporting no one was seriously hurt.

title: Mendiburu Foundation holding Cupid’s Challenge fundraiser Feb. 12
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — The Mendiburu Foundation will hold its annual Cupid’s Challenge event on Feb. 12.
Each sale will support the Mendiburu Magic Foundation, which helps local children with cancer and other life-threatening illnesses.
The boxes cost $20 each and can be purchased in person on Feb. 12 or online through Feb. 29.
To purchase a box online, visit https://bit.ly/2OywXDS.
For more information about the Mendiburu Magic Foundation, visit https://www.mendiburumagic.org.

title: Series of closures on Highway 99 starts tomorrow
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — A series of closures on Highway 99 are expected to begin on Thursday.
The westbound 58-to-southbound Highway 99 connector ramp will also be closed at the same time.
The California Department of Transportation is also planning a daytime closure on southbound Highway 99 off-ramp to Rosedale Highway on Thursday from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. for landscape maintenance operations.
On Tuesday, and Thursday, February 13, northbound Highway 99 will have the same closure.
These closures are needed to erect falsework for the widening of the westbound Highway 58 bridge across the 99.

title: Bakersfield police say a stabbing in East Bakersfield sent one man to the hospital Sunday afternoon
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — The Bakersfield Police Department responded to a stabbing call in East Bakersfield that sent one man to a local hospital Sunday evening.
BPD said the stabbing occurred at about 11:54 a.m., in the 900 block of Monterey Street.
The victim was transported to the hospital and is expected to survive.
A suspect has not been located, according to officials.
Check back for updates.

title: Kern County Sheriff’s Activities league hosting Fishing Derby
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) – The Kern County Sheriff’s Activities League is hosting their 16th annual Fishing Derby on February 29.
The derby will be at the Park at Riverwalk from 7 a.m. to 12 p.m.
Along with fishing, there will be a raffle, prizes, face panting and trophies.
A tagged fish will be in the water worth a $200 cash prize.
Admission is $8 for people 17 and under and $15 for adults.

title: Man dies after suffering medical emergency while driving
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — A man apparently suffered a medical emergency while driving Thursday and died after his vehicle left the roadway, according to police.
Officers were called to a report of a crash in the 5400 block of White Lane around 10:30 a.m., police said.
Emergency medical personnel and officers tried to resuscitate the driver — who was in apparent medical distress — but he was pronounced dead at the scene.
The coroner’s office will later release the man’s name, and determine manner and cause of death.
Anyone with information regarding this incident is asked to call the Bakersfield Police Department at 327-7111.

title: Boy dies after rollover crash in Shafter Friday
summary:
UPDATE: The child involved in the rollover crash that happened in Shafter, Friday afternoon, has died.
According to the Kern County Sheriff’s Office, Jaden Jimenez, 6, died in Kern Medical Friday at 4:45 p.m. as a result of his injuries.
He was a passenger of the vehicle that left the roadway and crashed in the 30000 block of West Tulare Avenue, just east of Poplar Avenue at 3:39 p.m.————SHAFTER, Calif. (KGET) — Shafter police said three people were injured, one seriously, Friday afternoon in a rollover crash on Tulare Avenue.
A juvenile inside a vehicle that rolled over into an orchard was not responding, according to the California Highway Patrol’s Traffic Incident Information Page.
Police said the Tulare Avenue between Poplar Avenue and Ryan Drive will be closed for several hours for the investigation.

title: At least one dead in traffic collision northeast of Bakersfield, according to CHP traffic website
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — At least one person is dead following a traffic collision northeast of Bakersfield Saturday afternoon, according to the California Highway Patrol.
The CHP traffic incident website shows that the collision occurred around 1:19 p.m. on Granite Road, just south of State Route 155 in Glennville.
The website does not indicate how the traffic collision occurred or how many people are involved, but the collision is listed as a "fatality."
Traffic may be restricted in the area.
Check back for updates.

title: Vehicle crashes into tree in central Bakersfield
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) - Because of the pandemic small businesses are being forced to temporarily shut down and owners are struggling to come up with cash to keep them running.
The federal government introduced the paycheck Protection Program to help them.

title: 20th Annual Kern County Teacher Recruitment Fair
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) – The 20th Annual Kern County Teacher Recruitment Fair took place Saturday morning at the Larry E. Reider Education Center.
The event is sponsored by the Kern County Superintendent of Schools Office as it is the country’s largest gathering of school district recruiters in one location.
“We need to make sure that our students have the teachers they need,” Coordinator of Teacher Development Program at the Kern County Superintendent Schools, Tania Schalburg-Dykes said.
“Starting early in February is a great way for districts to meet teachers.”Several school districts are also recruiting Career Technical Education (CTE) teachers.
Individuals who have a high school diploma or equivalent with at least three years of experience in the following industries are needed:

title: Local family featured on Extreme Makeover: Home Edition shares experience; episode airs Sunday
summary:
— In August of 2019, a local family's lives changed forever, once they were chosen to appear on HGTV's show, Extreme Makeover: Home Edition.
Single mom, Jessica Mosley, a mother to five aged 12-to-16, three which she adopted, say their new home is truly a reflection of them all.
The family says they don’t think they will ever get over their new dream home, thanks to the community's help.
The Mosley kids say their experience with Extreme Makeover: Home Edition has changed their lives forever.
Extreme Makeover: Home Edition on HGTV premieres this Sunday at 9 p.m.

title: Job Fest 2020 series kicks off with first event in Lamont in February
summary:
On Monday, Job Fest Kern County unveiled its schedule for 2020.
The first Job Fest will take place Feb. 13 in Lamont, followed by an event in Mojave on Feb. 27.
The Lake Isabella Job Fest will take place April 2 with the Ridgecrest event taking place April 23.
Two Job Fest events are scheduled for May - May 7 in Taft and May 21 in Shafter.
For more information contact evetts@kerndhs.com or visit the Job Fest Facebook page.

title: UPDATED: Sheriff’s Office assists in state raids on marijuana shops in Northeast Bakersfield
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) – The state Bureau of Cannabis Control issued search warrants at two local pot shops yesterday after they were found to be operating without a license.
According to the bureau, the shops were Knotts Collective at 902 Knotts Street and Backyard Organics, located at 2111 River Boulevard.
At Backyard Organics, cannabis flowers, edibles and cannabis concentrate were seized, an estimated retail value of nearly $185,000.
The bureau said the state cannot issue any commercial cannabis licenses to a county that has a ban in place.
Tuesday’s raid comes just days after the sheriff’s office raided four other dispensaries in Bakersfield.

title: Driver Arrested After Hours-Long Chase to Bakersfield and Back
summary:
It was a long night for California Highway Patrol after a man led police on a chase from Montebello to Bakersfield and back again.
CHP said the driver was initially wanted for reckless driving by the Montebello Police Department.
NewsChopper4 Bravo was over the pursuit around 9:10 p.m. in Sylmar, where the vehicle was seen traveling at normal speeds.
The pursuit carried on for over four hours as the driver drove to Bakersfield and back again.
No other vehicles were in the immediate area of the pursuit, except for a few CHP cruisers behind the car.

summary:

title: 41 have tested positive for coronavirus in Kern: Public Health
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — Numbers updated late Friday afternoon show a total of 41 people have tested positive for COVID-19 in Kern County.
Public health officials have tested 1,777 people.
There have been 765 negative results, and 971 results are pending, according to the county’s public health website.
Also Friday, Ridgecrest Regional Hospital reported a second person has tested positive for the virus among samples that were collected at the hospital.
“We had expected this,” said Jim Suver, president/CEO of Ridgecrest Regional Hospital in a news release.

title: UPDATE: Gun discarded after fatal shooting found, fired by boy
summary:
UPDATE (March 16): BPD said that at around 1 p.m. on Sunday, officers were sent to a residence in the 4100 block of Whitegate Avenue regarding a firearm that had been located.
The department said a 10-year-old boy found a firearm in his backyard.
The parent of the boy immediately responded and took the gun from the boy.
UPDATE (March 13): On Thursday, the Bakersfield Police Department arrested two people in connection with the murder of Joshua Rocha.
It is believed that the gun was discarded by one of the suspects in the area of the 4100 block of Whitegate Avenue.

title: Thousands descend on Downtown Bakersfield for third annual Women’s March Kern County
summary:
The third annual Women’s March Kern County took place in Downtown Bakersfield Saturday.
The event started at 10 am at Central Park at Mill Creek on 21st Street and ended after the march at 3 pm.
“It’s all about empowering women and the community,” said co-director Robin Walters.
The father of two attending today’s festivities to give thanks to all the women in his life.

summary:

title: Despite rumors Public Health officials said there are no confirmed coronavirus cases in Kern County
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — According to Kern County Public Health there are still no confirmed coronavirus cases in Kern County despite several rumors that are circulating.
Michelle Corson, the spokesperson for the Kern County Public Health Department, they are still monitoring only ten people for the virus.
We will continue to work alongside the Health Department to bring you the very latest from what is transpiring within the county.

title: Coronavirus not in Kern County, precautions being taken
summary:
Locally, the overall risk of COVID-19 remains low and Kern Public Health wants to remind the public that there is no need to panic.
The Centers for Disease Control says there are one-hundred and sixty-four confirmed cases in the U.S. and eleven deaths.
Kern Public Health has tested four people for Coronavirus.
Kern Public Health is also monitoring three travelers to see if they’re at risk for the virus.
Public health also says its expanding testing measures to include Kern County, anticipating more testing in the coming days and weeks.

title: EVENT CANCELLATIONS: Bakersfield, State, and National
summary:
LOS ANGELES (AP) — In these dark times, clouded by fears of an enemy we can’t see and sheltered in homes we're itching to leave, it's reassuring to know that California's sunsets over the Pacific are just as vivid.
You just can't enjoy them with sand between your toes.
Most beaches and virtually every other destination in California are closed because of the coronavirus outbreak.
Gavin Newsom has written off the possibility of a typical summer.
It could be one where you travel on the internet, have your temperature checked before being seated in a half-empty restaurant and worry about tan lines from your face mask.

title: California now has 69 confirmed coronavirus cases
summary:
California now has 69 confirmed cases of the coronavirus, according to the California Department of Public Health.
The department said 45 of the cases are not connected to repatriation flights.
Twelve of the cases are from person-to-person contact and nine from community transmission.
Currently, nearly 10,000 people are being monitored for the virus who returned to the U.S. through San Francisco International Airport or LAX.
The department said 49 local health jurisdictions are conducting self-monitoring.

title: Public health monitoring 10 people for possible coronavirus, still no confirmed cases in county
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — Kern County Public Health is currently monitoring 10 people for coronavirus, according to a briefing Friday morning.
Public health spokesperson Michelle Corson said there are still no confirmed cases in the county.
Locally labs testing for coronavirus include Quest Diagnostics, Westpac, Labcore and ARUP.
These labs are testing samples submitted through doctors orders.
Corson wants to remind the public that people cannot just walk into these labs and request to be tested.

title: UPDATE: March for Peace canceled over COVID-19 concerns
summary:
UPDATE (March 12): The Bakersfield Police Department announced the March for Peace event scheduled for March 13, has been canceled.
___The Bakersfield Safe Streets Partnership is holding a March for Peace next week.
The event will be held on March 13 from 3:30-6 p.m. at MLK Park, located at 1000 S. Owens St.
Besides the march, it will include a barbecue catered by Brenda Jean’s, live music, a carnival, resource fair and more.
“The gang and gun violence needs to stop and it is time we feel safe walking around in our own neighborhood,” the organization said in a post on its Facebook page.

title: Churches in Kern County respond to coronavirus outbreak, make changes
summary:
The Diocese of Fresno, which oversees all catholic churches in Kern County, has decided, starting on Monday, March 16-29 to suspend all parish operations.
The Bridge Bible Church released this video, stating they too are postponing and canceling church services, gatherings, and group activities.
"However, this does not mean the Bridge Bible Church worship is on hold or canceled," said Jeff Gowling, lead pastor of Bridge Bible Church.
City Serve, a non-profit which unites over 100 churches in Kern County, to help assist those in need are responding to the outbreak.
For a complete list of all the cancellations here in Kern County and California be sure to follow this link.

title: Bakersfield City School District to close all schools Wednesday due to COVID-19 concern
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) – The Bakersfield City School District has announced they will close campuses starting Wednesday due to the coronavirus concern.
According to the district’s Twitter account, they will close their campus until further notice.
BCSD said they will provide meals to all interested students 18 years and younger.
Location, times will be announced and more information will be forthcoming.

title: Amazon to be at Bakersfield Job Fest March 11 to provide information on new fulfillment facility
summary:
The next in the Job Fest Kern County series will feature one of the biggest employers in the world.
On Monday, Frank Cabrera and Josh Conner with Job Fest Kern County and the County's Human Services Department announced that Amazon will be at the March 11 Bakersfield Job Fest.
Cabrera and Conner said Amazon will not be hiring on site and will not be accepting applications at Job Fest.
They will also be taking questions from Job Fest attendees.
The Bakersfield Job Fest will run from 8 a.m. to noon at the Mechanics Bank Convention Center on March 11.

title: Kern County’s unemployment rate rises to 8.6% in January
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — January’s unemployment numbers in Kern County saw a jump from the previous reporting period according to state officials.
The Employment Development Department says the unemployment rate for Kern County in January was 8.6%.
The rate is up from 7.1% in December, but remains lower than January 2019 which was at 9%.
For comparison, California’s unemployment rate was at 4.3% in January continuing historic low rates.

title: UPDATE: Family identifies bicyclist killed in collision in northeast Bakersfield
summary:
UPDATE: The family of a bicyclist killed in a collision yesterday has identified him as Ismael Arrenaviz.
“He was a family man, he was always there when anybody needed help, he was a man of God,” she said.
The Bakersfield Police Department said the collision happened at about 11:41 a.m., police said.
Another vehicle collided with the rear of the vehicle that struck the bicyclist, after the first collision occurred, BPD said.
The driver of the vehicle that struck the bicyclist was not found to be under the influence and was released at the scene, the department said.

title: Here's every current polling place in Kern County for the March 3 primary election
summary:
KERN COUNTY, Calif. — Super Tuesday is next week and if you plan on voting at a polling location in Kern County, here's every available location.
To find out more about each polling location, such as what party they cater to and who the election officers are, visit kernvote.com.
Polls open on March 3, also known as Super Tuesday, at 6 a.m. and close at 8 p.m.

title: Health officials announce closure of all Kern County schools
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — Health and school officials announce temporary closure of all Kern County schools to fight against the spread of COVID-19.
According to a press release by the Kern County Public Health Department, health officials, along with the Kern County Superintendent of Schools have decided to close all Kern county public schools.
"Although there have been no confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Kern County, we are recommending that all Kern County K-12 schools, preschools, and charter schools close temporarily, no later than the close of school on Wednesday, March 18, 2020," the release states.
"We are further recommending that Kern County public schools plan to reopen no earlier than Tuesday, April 14, 2020," the release states.
At 7:44 p.m., county health and school officials sent 23ABC News a press release, announcing the temporary closure of schools in Kern County.

title: Kern County announces dates for 2020 Job Fest series
summary:
The Kern County Department of Human Services has announced dates for its 2020 Job Fest series.
Job Fest highlights available job opportunities and openings throughout the county.
The event will make stops throughout the county starting in early February and lasting into June.
Here’s a list of all the upcoming events.
Nearly all of them take place between 9 a.m. and noon.

title: Public health says one more local resident being tested for coronavirus
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — Another local resident is being tested for coronavirus, the Kern County Public Health Services Department announced in its daily video briefing Friday.
Public Health spokesperson Michelle Corson said the Center for Disease Control and Prevention confirmed they have tested five people total from Kern County and one of those tests came back negative.
Corson said they are also monitoring residents who have traveled internationally and been allowed to return home because they are not showing symptoms.
According to Corson, public health was given 15 names to monitor and as of Friday morning, 11 of those names no longer need to be monitored.
Corson advises anyone who plans to travel visit the public health website to stay up-to-date on all the travel advisories in-place.

summary:

title: Alleged drunk driver dies in car crash
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — A 64-year-old man who might have been under the influence, drove off the roadway westbound on State Route 58.
The Bakersfield Communication Center received a call of a solo car crash on State Route 58 west Lokern Road, with medical personnel responding.
Officers from the California Highway Patrol Buttonwillow Area Office responded to the scene and investigated the car crash.
At approximately 9:30 PM, he was transported to Kern Medical by air ambulance where he died due to his injuries.
According to CHP, alcohol use is being investigated as a potential factor of this solo crash.

title: Shooting in East Bakersfield leaves one person Injured
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — The Kern County Sheriff's Office is investigating a shooting in East Bakersfield that left one person injured.
Deputies responded to Earl Avenue just before 11 p.m. Friday after calls for shots fired.
They located one victim at the scene, who was then transported to a local hospital.
The victim did not sustain life-threatening injuries, according to KCSO.
If you have any information, contact the Sheriff's Office at 861-3110.

title: Bakersfield water board meeting canceled
summary: BAKERSFIELD, Calif. —The city of Bakersfield water board has canceled its March 18 meeting to be held at noon in the Water Resources Building Conference room.

title: What you need to know: voters to decide Kern medicinal cannabis on March 3
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — Come Tuesday, March 3, Kern County voters will decide on two medicinal cannabis measures.
Measure DMeasure D will allow medicinal cannabis dispensaries that were legally operating for January 1, 2018 to apply for a permit.
Those in favor of Measure D argue revenue may go towards law enforcement, drug treatment, and K-12 schools.
Those against Measure D argue the Medicinal Cannabis Measure will permit shops that have closed to reopen or even expand with no new regulations, all with no public hearing or community input.
Those for the county measure argue it provides a clean-slate for the cannabis industry, but with regulation and community input.

title: Second person dies from coronavirus in California
summary:
Health officials in Santa Clara County announced Monday a woman has died of COVID-19, making her the second person in California killed by the virus.
The patient was a woman in her 60s who had no known history of international travel or contact with a person who was infected, leading officials to believe she contracted the virus within the county’s local community, according to the Santa Clara County Public Health Department.
“This is a tragic development.
The Public Health Department is taking necessary, carefully considered steps to slow down the spread of the disease and to protect those at greatest risk,” Dr. Sara Cody, the county’s health officer, said in a news release.
The death was announced within an hour of health officials in L.A. County reporting the area’s first possible case of “community transfer.”

title: Three people escape scene of rollover crash in Downtown Bakersfield
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — Police say three people fled from their vehicle after being involved in a rollover crash just off Highway 178 Wednesday night in Downtown Bakersfield.
CHP reported the crash happened at the westbound offramp of Highway 178 at M Street just after 9 p.m.Officers on scene told 17 News three people inside the pickup truck managed to get out and run from the scene.
It was unknown if anyone of them was injured.
Anyone with information on the crash is asked to call Bakersfield police at 327-7111.

title: Open house to discuss Bakersfield’s High Speed Rail route
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — Representatives with the California High-Speed Rail Authority will be in Bakersfield Thursday to answer questions and listen to comments on the project.
Thursday’s open house will focus on the Environmental Impact Report for the Bakersfield to Palmdale route.
The open house takes place Thursday, March 5 at Edison Middle School from 5:30 p.m. to 7:30 p.m.Edison Middle School is located at 721 Edison Road.

title: Bakersfield mayoral candidates share vision for city ahead of KGET debate Monday
summary:
Four of the five candidates running for Bakersfield mayor shared their visions for the city.

title: Farmworkers, Mostly Undocumented, Become ‘Essential’ During Pandemic
summary:
Since March 16, Ms. Fabian has worked four-hour shifts most days, and been told not to report at all on other days.
She assumes that her employer has thinned the packing lines because, with schools closed, demand for packed fruit is down.
But we are more afraid that we won’t be able to make a living,” said Ms. Fabian, a single mother who bought a house in October, where she lives with her three children.
In Idaho, where a statewide stay-at-home order began on March 25, dairy owners are scrambling to ensure that the industry’s 8,000 workers, 90 percent of them undocumented, can keep working.
Even before the virus, the industry, which needs workers year-round to milk the cows, had been grappling with a labor shortfall.

title: Dust Bowl festival celebrates its 30th and final year
summary:
The Dust Bowl festival, which honors those who migrated to California in the 1930s, will celebrate its final year.

“Those people came out with a hard work ethic, so they came here looking for better times, something to feed their family,” said Mack Wimbish with the Dust Bowl Committee.
In the future, the celebration will be smaller and held at the Dust Bowl labor camp that the original migrants lived in.
“What the people went through, the suffering they went through–just to live and work here back in those days.

title: Red flag warning issued for Kern County mountains for ‘critical fire weather conditions’
summary:
KERN COUNTY MOUNTAINS, Calif. (KGET) — The National Weather Service has issued a red flag warning for areas including Lake Isabella, Tehachapi and Fort Tejon for “critical fire weather conditions.”The warning goes into effect 10 a.m. Thursday and lasts until 5 p.m. Friday.
The forecast calls for low humidity and wind gusts of up to 35 mph in the mountain areas.
“The combination of very dry fuels, gusty winds, and low humidities can create a hazardous environment for the ignition and spread of wildfires,” the National Weather Service said.
“Outdoor burning is not recommended.”The warning comes as PG&E is shutting down power to hundreds of thousands of customers throughout the state due to elevated fire risk.
A total of 42,374 Kern County PG&E customers may be affected.

title: 10 million pot plants worth $1 billion destroyed in Kern County
authors: Alex Wigglesworth Is A Staff Writer At The Los Angeles Times.
summary:
Authorities in Kern County destroyed about 10 million marijuana plants being grown under the guise of industrial hemp.
Investigators with the Kern County Sheriff’s Office seized the plants, which they estimate to have a street value of more than $1 billion, from 11 fields in the Arvin area on Oct. 25, according to a news release from the Sheriff’s Office.
Industrial hemp grown for commercial sale must, by law, contain no more than 0.3% THC, though there’s an exemption for hemp grown for research purposes, the Sheriff’s Office said.
Kern County voted to ban commercial cannabis activity in 2017.
No arrests were made, and authorities haven’t determined whether they’ll seek charges, a spokeswoman for the Sheriff’s Office said.

title: COVID-19 is wrecking the state budget and it’s time for the high-speed rail project to go
summary:
One especially easy cost-saving opportunity would be to delay or cancel the high-speed rail project, which is now expected to cost taxpayers $80 billion for the full system promised to voters in 2008.
And building high-speed rail in the Central Valley is far from essential.
The latest California High-Speed Rail Authority (CHSRA) business plan calls for the start of service between Merced and Bakersfield in 2028-29.
The Trump administration, however, has already said it will not provide additional rail money for multiple reasons, including inadequate reporting by CHSRA.
But shutting down or scaling back the high-speed rail project should not be a difficult decision for California.

In exchange for helping out, volunteers will earn a free admission pass to Holiday Lights for each full night worked.
According to the museum, volunteers need to be at least 17 years-old.

title: Bakersfield student selected as finalist for statewide video contest
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — A local student has made it to the top five as a finalist for a statewide video contest.
Erubiel Monterrosa of Bakersfield is one of the final five entries in the "2019 Districts Makes The Difference" video contest.
High school and college students were challenged to create a 60 to 90 second video showing the importance of special districts by highlighting how they have enhanced the lives of residents by providing essential services such as water, energy, fire protection and more.
Erubiel used local scenery to creatively show the important role that special districts have in our communities.
First prize will be awarded $2000, Second will be awarded $1000, and Third will be awarded $500.

title: Country singer Brett Young coming to Bakersfield in April
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — Orange County's own Brett Young is coming to Bakersfield and the Rabobank Arena on Sunday, April 26th.
Young started out as college baseball pitcher, but turned to music following a career-ending elbow injury.
He released a six song EP in February 2016 followed a year later with his self-titled debut album.
Young has had five Top 5 songs, including "Sleep Without You," "In Case You Didn't Know," "Like I Loved You," "Mercy," and "Here Tonight" and was named the ACM New Male Vocalist of the Year in 2018.
Tickets for the show go on sale on Friday, November 8 at 10 a.m.

title: Freebies, deals on tap for Veterans Day
summary:

FOOD DEALSApplebee’s: Current and former military members can select a free meal from a limited menu at participating restaurants.

title: 50-year-old woman killed in collision near Valley Plaza Mall in South Bakersfield
summary:

title: Bakersfield Police Department investigating deadly vehicle versus pedestrian crash in Northwest Bakersfield
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — The Bakersfield Police Department is investigating a deadly vehicle versus pedestrian crash that happened in Northwest Bakersfield Tuesday evening.
Officers were called to Coffee Rd.
According to police, an adult man, approximately 85 years old, was crossing Coffee Road outside of a crosswalk when a driver hit him.
Investigators said the man crossing the road died at the scene.
The identity of the man who died will be released by the Kern County Coroner's Office at a later time.

title: Yard House in Bakersfield looking to hire for all positions
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — Back in February, the Yard House announced that it was coming to Bakersfield.
And now the sports bar chain is looking to fill over 200 open positions at it's new Stockdale Highway location.
Among the positions available are: servers, hosts, bussers, barbacks, bartenders, expeditors, line cooks, prep cooks and dishwashers.
Interested applicants can walk-in to apply in person (10308 Stockdale Highway), by texting code BAKERSFIELD to 37238 or apply online on their website.

title: BC celebrating Veterans Day with activities throughout November, early December
summary:
Bakersfield College is celebrating Veterans Day with events throughout November and beyond.
The college will kick things off on Nov. 4 with a Veterans Community Leader Breakfast, followed by the annual Vet Fest on Nov. 6 from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. in front of the CSS building, 1801 Panorama Dr.Other highlights include programs from two veterans and public speakers: Jason Beardsley on Nov. 7 and Dave Gutierrez on Dec. 3.
The activities end on Dec. 10 with the unveiling of the new Vernon Valenzuela Veterans Resource Center at 10 a.m. in front of the center.
For more information or a full list of activities, call 661-395-4011.

title: Spending for California’s bullet train divides state leaders as never before
authors: A Former National Correspondent At The Los Angeles Times
summary:
Even after a decade of abrupt U-turns for California’s high-speed rail project, state leaders are now split like never before.
For the record: A previous version of this story misspelled the names of rail authority board member Daniel Curtin and Assemblyman Jim Frazier.
The authority argues that it would demonstrate to voters and private investors that the state can actually build and operate a bullet train.
The moves follow several other changes of bullet train personnel in recent months.
Rendon began the debate this summer when he called for spending more money on the bullet train route from Burbank to Anaheim and in San Francisco.

title: Unemployment rate drops slightly in Kern County
summary:
According to the State of California Employment Division, the unemployment rate dipped slightly in November compared to the same time last year.
The unemployment rate of 6.4% for November 2019 was slightly lower than the 6.5% in November 2018.
That is still significantly higher than the state of California's unemployment rate of 3.7% for California and 3.3% for the nation during the same period.
Manufacturing saw a loss of 300 jobs compared to November 2018, with construction and financial industries seeing a loss of 200.
The data provided by the State of California Employment Division is not adjusted for seasonality.

title: Kern County's top stories in 2019
summary:
Homeless crisisThe number of unsheltered homeless individuals more than doubled in 2019 from the year prior, prompting the county to declare a homeless crisis and a homeless shelter crisis.
John Wooner found deadIn July, officials found the body of Mcfarland City Manager John Wooner in the Kern River.
The Kern County District Attorney's office announced that Martin will serve as a chief district attorney's investigator.
Kern County Fair State AuditIn September the Kern County District Attorney's Office confirmed that it launched an investigation into Kern County fair officials following a state audit revealing that hundreds of thousands of dollars were mismanaged by a fair CEO and maintenance supervisor.
Kern County high school state titlesBakersfield Christian High School won their first state football title and Foothill High School won their second state basketball title.

title: In California, The Teen Birth Rate Has Hit A Record Low. How?
summary:
That’s the 16th lowest teen birth rate in the nation, and below the national average of nearly 19 births per 1,000 females in that age range.
Even so, teen birth rates are falling in every California county — sometimes dramatically.
California law allows anyone under 18 to seek birth control services or the morning-after pill on their own.
Erica Diaz-Rodriguez grew up in Woodlake, a town of 7,000 in Tulare County, a county with the state’s second-highest teen birth rate.
The counties where teen moms are more commonIncome inequality and cultural factors also played a role in counties with high teen birth rates.

title: Final farewell to Commander Ian Chandler
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) – A final farewell to Kern County Sheriff’s Commander Ian Chandler, a beloved member of law enforcement known for his kindness and humility.
“They say the good always go first and with Ian, that’s what happened,” said Carl Sparks, retired Kern County Sheriff.
“He had so much more to give to the community and the Sheriff’s Department.
“Ian was a special man and this is indicative of someone who was well-loved,” said Kevin Zimmermann, Shafter police chief.
“I saw leadership from the city of Wasco, from the Sheriff’s Office, from the Police Department, community leaders, the DA was here.

title: Storm expected to hit Kern County Christmas Day
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — A strong storm is expected to hit the greater Kern County area by the afternoon of Christmas Day.
KGET forecasters issued a Winter Storm Warning for all of the Kern County Mountains above 3,000ft.
Some areas including Tehachapi, Bear Valley Springs, Stallion Springs, Frazier Park, and Pine Mountain Club could see up to 12 inches of snow by Thursday morning.

title: BPD: Motorcyclist dies following collision with mail truck on Ming Ave.

BPD said the motorcyclist was reportedly traveling eastbound on Ming at a high rate of speed before colliding with the rear end of a mail truck.
Police said in result of the crash, the mail truck ended up flipping over.
The driver of the mail truck sustained minor injuries.

title: House supply, sales dropped in Kern County last month
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — January saw home supply and demand in Kern County continue to decline, local appraiser Gary Crabtree says.
New listings last month dropped 6.4 percent from 722 in December 2019 to 676 last month.
Crabtree said home sales dropped 15.4 percent from 564 in December to 477.
However, Crabtree said what is unusual is that the median sale price dropped by $13,500 last month, or 5.1 percent.
The median price was $251,000 compared to $264,500 in December.

title: Attempted carjacking in Central Bakersfield
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — Five juveniles and two adults were detained following an attempted car jacking that Bakersfield Police say took place in Central Bakersfield on December 12, at 9 p.m.
According to police, a person flagged down police in the 3600 block of Q street to report a attempted carjacking.
Police located and detained five juveniles and two adult males in connection to the attempted car jacking.
An investigation determined that the same 17 year old was responsible for the attempted carjacking.
The 17 year old was also charged with attempted carjacking.

title: Possible hit-and-run near Walmart in South Bakersfield
summary:
LOS ANGELES (AP) — In these dark times, clouded by fears of an enemy we can’t see and sheltered in homes we're itching to leave, it's reassuring to know that California's sunsets over the Pacific are just as vivid.
You just can't enjoy them with sand between your toes.
Most beaches and virtually every other destination in California are closed because of the coronavirus outbreak.
Gavin Newsom has written off the possibility of a typical summer.
It could be one where you travel on the internet, have your temperature checked before being seated in a half-empty restaurant and worry about tan lines from your face mask.

summary:

A struggle ensued and Jones and Deputy Leask fell down a flight of stairs to the ground.

title: Motorcyclist hospitalized following hit-and-run collision; Fleeing driver arrested
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) — A motorcyclist has been hospitalized following a collision Tuesday evening in Southwest Bakersfield and police say the woman behind the wheel of the SUV involved hid in a nearby restaurant.
The collision happened at around 5:35 p.m. in the 200 block of Coffee Road just north of the intersection at Gosford Road and Stockdale Highway.
Police said the motorcyclist — identified as an adult male — suffered moderate to major injuries and was taken to hospital where he was listed as critical.
According to police, the woman identified as Trumonikia Fields-Johnson, 40, was driving a white SUV northbound on Coffee Road and made an unsafe lane change colliding with the motorcyclist.
Police said they found the suspected vehicle abandoned nearby and Fields-Johnson was found inside a restaurant trying to hide from officers.

The suspects involved ran from the scene toward Costco and Carls Jr. on Rosedale Highway.
Officers chased two male suspects on foot and on their police cars.
BPD confirmed they arrested both male suspects on the parking lot of Costco, by the gas pumps, and the firearm was found at the scene.
The identity of the victim and the suspects have not yet been released.

title: Third person arrested in connection to December shooting in Wasco
summary:

According to the Kern County Sheriff's Office, 21-year-old Samuel Olivia of McFarland was arrested Friday and booked on charges of attempted murder, robbery and conspiracy.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — Update: Jose Velasquez, the man suspected of shooting and killing a man in Southeast Bakersfield last month, pleaded not guilty to charges of second-degree murder and reckless discharge of a firearm.

title: Bakersfield anesthesiologist suspended after creating false medical records to prescribe medication
summary:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — A Bakersfield anesthesiologist has been put on a five year probation and a 15-day suspension for creating false medical records and prescribing medication without an appropriate medical exam for several patients.

Documents said Madrid "created false medical records with fraudulent intent and failure to maintain adequate and accurate medical records in the care and treatment of seven patients."
Madrid's 15-day suspension begins on December 29.

title: The Very Essential Work of Street-Level Violence Prevention
authors: David Muhammad Is The Executive Director Of The National Institute For Criminal Justice Reform.
Devone Boggan Is The Executive Director Of Advance Peace.
summary:
The Very Essential Work of Street-Level Violence Prevention On the frontlines of the coronavirus pandemic, outreach workers are going beyond their mission of preventing shootings by filling gaps in social services.
With law enforcement spread thin because of officers contracting the virus and many social service agencies suspending their work, violence prevention specialists are desperately needed.
In Stockton, California, the mayor declared the Office of Violence Prevention’s peacekeepers as essential workers.
Violence prevention specialists in cities across the country work with people and families who are impoverished, underserved, and disadvantaged.
And like other frontline essential workers, violence prevention specialists are in desperate need of personal protective equipment, including masks and gloves.
